history.content:
I'm gonna have to disagree with the last part where you mention that "there's nothing in data 8 that's useful for data 100." The probability and statistical inference portion of Data 8 (which you haven't gotten to yet) does help give you intuition for topics like sampling and linear regression in Data 100. Topics like bootstrapping introduced in Data 8 come up in Data 100 under different contexts. In terms of just programming, you may be correct, but programming isn't really the focus of these classes anyway. Just like its title implies, Data 8 provides some foundational tools of data science which are expanded upon or applied in subsequent courses like Data 100 

-----

^ I'm just giving my point of view with my context of programming and statistical skills.

---

^ I think you're missing the point, and in turn, giving bad/uninformed advice. For those who have taken Data 8, the stats portion is useful for Data 100. The stats content covered in Data 8, in my opinion, is rigorous enough for the level of Data 100. It may have not been as challenging in the beginning if you had taken Data 8 prior.

children.subject: There’s a ton of material in Data 8 that ends up supplementing content in 100, programming wise but especially statistics wise. Data 8 introduces sampling techniques, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, and regression, all of which 100 covers and expands on. That’s a lot to pick up if you haven’t seen it all before – I mean, there’s a reason the courses are set up so that 8 is a pre-req for 100.

history.content:
I decided to take Data 8 and Data 100 together this semester, and I thought I should give some precautions. I have no stats background, just for context. I've only taken 61A and 61B.

Data 8 is consistently easy. You can complete hw/labs in 10 mins if you have some programming experience. Data 8 uses a python library called datascience, which is a high level wrapper for pandas and matplotlib.

Data 100 is very challenging in the beginning, just because they moved the stats portion upfront. Data 100 hw usually takes one hour to complete, and the labs take about 30 mins. The first project took me three days to complete, with a couple of hours every day. One thing to note is that Data 100 uses pandas and matplotlib directly, and this is the main issue in taking both classes concurrently: Both classes use and teach the same functions but for different libraries, so you will constantly have to switch between some function name/args that do the same thing but look vastly different. This will cause a headache and will prevent you from memorizing such functions.

If you want to take both, do data 8 and data 100 in separate semesters. It doesn't matter which order because there's nothing in data 8 that's useful for data 100.
history.subject: Warning for anyone considering taking Data 8 and Data 100 concurrently
